title: Boxing Terminology
description: Step into the ring and test your knowledge of boxing terms!

questions.question: In boxing, what is a 'southpaw'?
options: A boxer who leads with jabs
questions.explanation: A southpaw is a left-handed boxer who leads with the right hand and right foot forward, the mirror image of the orthodox stance.

questions.question: What does 'TKO' stand for in boxing?
questions.explanation: TKO stands for Technical Knockout, when the referee stops the fight because one boxer cannot safely continue, even though they have not been knocked down for a full count.

questions.question: In boxing, what is 'rope-a-dope'?
options: A training drill using ring ropes
A penalty for holding the ropes
A strategy of leaning on the ropes and letting the opponent tire themselves out
A style of jumping rope for conditioning
questions.explanation: Rope-a-dope is a strategy famously used by Muhammad Ali, where a boxer leans against the ropes, absorbs punches, and lets the opponent exhaust themselves before counterattacking.

questions.question: What is a 'standing eight count' in boxing?
options: Counting to eight before the bell rings
A mandatory count given to a standing but hurt boxer
questions.explanation: A standing eight count is when the referee temporarily stops the action to count to eight and assess whether a standing but visibly hurt boxer can safely continue.

questions.question: In boxing, what is an 'uppercut'?
options: A vertical rising punch thrown upward toward the chin
A quick straight punch to the body
A downward chop to the shoulder
questions.explanation: An uppercut is a powerful vertical punch thrown in an upward arc, typically targeting the opponent's chin or solar plexus at close range.

questions.question: What does 'throwing in the towel' mean in boxing?
options: A foul for using a foreign object
A corner stopping the fight by tossing a towel into the ring
questions.explanation: Throwing in the towel is when a boxer's corner team tosses a towel into the ring to signal they want the fight stopped, conceding defeat to protect their fighter.

questions.question: In boxing, what is a 'clinch'?
options: Holding or grappling an opponent at close range to prevent punching
questions.explanation: A clinch occurs when a boxer grabs or holds the opponent at close range, tying up their arms to prevent further exchanges, often used as a defensive tactic.

questions.question: What is a 'rabbit punch' in boxing?
options: An illegal punch to the back of the head or neck
questions.explanation: A rabbit punch is an illegal blow to the back of the head or neck, named after the method used to dispatch rabbits. It is banned because it can cause serious spinal injury.

questions.question: In boxing, what does 'pound for pound' mean?
options: A ranking of fighters regardless of weight class based on overall skill
The exchange rate of punches landed
The cost of a boxing match per pound of weight
questions.explanation: Pound for pound is a ranking concept that attempts to determine the best boxer regardless of weight class, evaluating skill, achievement, and dominance relative to competition.

questions.question: What is the 'sweet science' a nickname for?
questions.explanation: Boxing is known as 'the sweet science,' a term popularized by sportswriter A.J. Liebling, referring to the skill, strategy, and artistry involved in the sport.

questions.question: In boxing, what is a 'haymaker'?
options: A jab followed by a cross
A punch aimed at the stomach
questions.explanation: A haymaker is a wild, looping, powerful punch thrown with maximum force, often sacrificing accuracy and leaving the thrower open to counter-punches.

questions.question: What is 'stick and move' in boxing?
options: A training exercise with a heavy bag
A strategy of jabbing and quickly moving to avoid counter-punches
questions.explanation: Stick and move is a boxing strategy where the fighter uses quick jabs ('sticks') and then immediately moves away to avoid being hit in return.

questions.question: In boxing, what is the 'neutral corner'?
options: Either of the two ring corners not assigned to a boxer
The corner where neither fighter's team sits
The corner closest to the judges
questions.explanation: The neutral corners are the two corners of the ring not occupied by either boxer's team. A fighter who scores a knockdown must retreat to a neutral corner while the referee counts.

questions.question: What does 'on the canvas' mean in boxing?
options: A boxer has been knocked down to the mat
Painting a mural at the venue
questions.explanation: 'On the canvas' means a boxer has been knocked down, referring to the canvas material covering the ring floor.

questions.question: In boxing, what is a 'body shot'?
options: A punch aimed at the opponent's torso
A shot of adrenaline given between rounds
A punch thrown while turning the body
questions.explanation: A body shot is a punch targeted at the opponent's torso, particularly the ribs and solar plexus, designed to weaken and slow the opponent over the course of a fight.
